citation.biblCit: Population Research Laboratory, 2018, "Alberta Survey, 2016B", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/UNAJUB, UAL Dataverse, V1, UNF:6:VOKru349/HqqFgamHTfYoQ== [fileUNF]

AuthEnty.affiliation: Department of Sociology, University of Alberta

stdyInfo.abstract: The Population Research Laboratory (PRL) administered the 2016 Alberta Survey B. This survey of households across the province of Alberta continues to enable academic researchers, government departments, and non-profit organizations to explore a wide range of topics in a structured research framework and environment. Sponsorsâ€™ research questions are asked together with demographic questions in a telephone interview of Alberta households.

dataColl.sampProc: The main feature of the sampling design was a two-stage selection process: first, based on a selection of households, and second, the selection of a respondent within each household. The Alberta Survey B aimed for a total sample size of 1,200 households across Alberta, with a minimum of 400 respondents in Metropolitan Edmonton, 400 in Metropolitan Calgary, and 400 from the remainder of the province (other Alberta). The target population are persons 18 years of age or older. The PRL used a Random-Digit Dialling (RDD) approach for landlines to ensure that respondents had an equal chance to be contacted whether or not their household was listed in a telephone directory. The PRL has developed a database of eight-digit telephone banks covering the Edmonton and Calgary metropolitan areas, as well as the remainder of the province. By area, the identified working banks are randomly selected with replacement and a randomly generated set of two digits between 00-99 is appended to each selection. Duplicate telephone numbers were purged from the computer list. Businesses and government exchanges were excluded. Within the household, one eligible person was selected as the respondent. In 2016, the sampling frames of telephone numbers included both land lines and cell phones. Cell phone listings were randomly generated by an outside vendor. When a cell phone was reached and the person preferred not to continue for personal, privacy and/or cost reasons, the interview was terminated.
dataColl.weight: The sample sizes of completed interviews obtained for Metropolitan Edmonton, Metropolitan Calgary, and Other Alberta are not always proportional to the current Alberta population they are meant to represent. Therefore, statistical weights were calculated for the 2016 Alberta Survey B sample data using population estimates for 2015.

anlyInfo.respRate: Response rates are calculated percentages representing the number of people who participated in the survey divided by the number selected in the eligible sample. The response rate for 2016 Alberta Survey B was 20.2%. The method used in this study is calculated as the number of completed interviews divided by the number of completed interviews, refusals, incompletes, and language problems.
anlyInfo.EstSmpErr: This study is based on a sample of adults in Alberta rather than the total population of adults in Alberta. All of the descriptive statistics, such as means and percentages, which are calculated using the sample data, are subject to sampling error. The sampling error is a measure of the validity of the descriptive statistics that are observed in a sample. The estimated sampling error, at the 95% confidence level, for an area sample of 1,208 households assuming a 50/50 binomial percentage distribution is plus or minus 2.8 percentage points. Survey estimates for the subsample of 400 are estimated to be within plus or minus 5.0 percentage points, at the 95% confidence level.

var.name: va1
var.labl: In the past six months, have you used social media?

var.name: va2a
var.labl: (YES) Various social media you use, do you follow, like or link to: Community organizations such as charities or non-profit organizations that raise funds or provide services to the less fortunate?

var.name: va2b
var.labl: (YES) Various social media you use, do you follow, like or link to: Political groups such as a political party or a political official, such as the mayor?

var.name: va2c
var.labl: (YES) Various social media you use, do you follow, like or link to: A political group that is not a political party, but advocates for political or social change, such as an environmental organization?

var.name: va2d
var.labl: (YES) Various social media you use, do you follow, like or link to: A news organization such as a local newspaper or TV news organization?

var.name: va3
var.labl: (YES) Have you been using social media to follow the Fort McMurray wildfire?

var.name: va4
var.labl: In the past 12 months, have you donated?

var.name: va5
var.labl: In the past 12 months, have you volunteered?

var.name: va6
var.labl: Have you been involved in any effort to help residents or first responders related to the Fort McMurray wildfire?

var.name: va7
var.labl: Thinking about your family, co-workers, and close friends, do you personally know anyone displaced by the Fort McMurray wildfire?

var.name: va8a
var.labl: Your thoughts about this statement: I care about others who live in Alberta.

var.name: va8b
var.labl: Your thoughts about this statement: It is important to support people who are worse off than oneself.

var.name: va8c
var.labl: Your thoughts about this statement: I am concerned for the people of Fort McMurray.

var.name: vb1
var.labl: Are you currently a mentor?

var.name: vb2
var.labl: (YES) Are you currently a mentor in...

var.name: vb3
var.labl: (YES) How long have you been a mentor (including both formal and informal mentoring)?

var.name: vb4
var.labl: (YES) What age group do your mentees fall within?

var.name: vb5
var.labl: At any time between ages 6 - 12 did you have a mentor?

var.name: vb6
var.labl: Looking back, do you recall a time between ages 6 - 12 when you did NOT have a mentor but wish you had had one whom you could have turned to for guidance and support?

var.name: vb7
var.labl: At any time between ages 13 - 24 did you have a mentor?

var.name: vb8
var.labl: Looking back, do you recall a time between ages 13 - 24 when you did NOT have a mentor but wish you had had one whom you could have turned to for guidance and support?

var.name: vb9
var.labl: How long was your longest mentoring relationship?

var.name: vb10a
var.labl: How would you rate the influence of this mentorship in terms of: Improving your interest in staying in school?

var.name: vb10b
var.labl: How would you rate the influence of this mentorship in terms of: Improving your social skills for building relationships?

var.name: vb10c
var.labl: How would you rate the influence of this mentorship in terms of: Improving your sense of pride or like for oneself?

var.name: vb10d
var.labl: How would you rate the influence of this mentorship in terms of: Improving your sense of confidence in your abilities?

var.name: vb10e
var.labl: How would you rate the influence of this mentorship in terms of: Improving your hope and optimism for the future?

var.name: vb11
var.labl: Would you consider being a mentor to a young person (ages 6-24 years) in the next three years?

var.name: vb12
var.labl: (YES) would you consider formal mentoring, informal mentoring or both?

var.name: vc1
var.labl: Your level of agreement: Alberta can learn from China's economic success.

var.name: vc2
var.labl: Your level of agreement: The ability to speak Chinese will become more important to Albertans.

var.name: vc3
var.labl: Your level of agreement: China is a stable trading partner for Alberta.

var.name: vc4
var.labl: Your level of agreement: Alberta should promote energy exports to China.

var.name: vc5
var.labl: Your level of agreement: Chinese investment in Alberta in the form of partial ownership is acceptable.

var.name: vc6
var.labl: Your level of agreement: Chinese investment in Alberta in the form of full ownership is acceptable.

var.name: vc7
var.labl: Your level of agreement: Investment in Alberta's energy sector by a company owned and operated by the Chinese government (state) is acceptable.

var.name: vc8
var.labl: Your level of agreement: Alberta should take China's human rights record into consideration when conducting business in China.

var.name: vc9
var.labl: Your level of agreement: China will overtake the United States as the leading global power in the 21st century.

var.name: vc10
var.labl: Your level of agreement: China's growing economic strength poses a threat to Canada.

var.name: vc11
var.labl: Your level of agreement: Investment from China in Alberta should be more regulated than foreign investment from elsewhere.

var.name: vc12
var.labl: Your level of agreement: Increased Chinese investment in Alberta contributes to the provincial economy.

var.name: vc13
var.labl: Your level of agreement: Alberta should collaborate with China in developing new technologies.

var.name: vc14
var.labl: Your level of agreement: The Canadian government should negotiate a Free Trade Agreement with China.

var.name: vd1
var.labl: When did you consider yourself to be in a common law relationship?

catgry.labl: After you and partner had lived together for 1 year
When you and partner moved in together
When you and partner had a child together
After you and partner had lived together for 3 years or more
You have never been in a common law relationship
When you and partner made a written agreement

var.name: vd2
var.labl: If currently married or in a common law relationship, do you and your spouse or partner have a written agreement about how you would divide your property if you split up?

catgry.labl: Not currently married or in a common law relationship

var.name: vd3
var.labl: What do you think Alberta law says about how a common law couple divides property when they split up?

catgry.labl: Equally divided property acquired by either partner
Each keeps their own property and divide only property owned jointly
Based on contributions which can be financial or non-financial

var.name: vd4
var.labl: Do you think that the rules about dividing property that apply to married couples would also be appropriate for common law couples?

var.name: vd5_1
var.labl: When do you think a common law couple that is splitting up should have to divide property like a married couple: Has lived together for a certain number of years?

var.name: vd5_2
var.labl: When do you think a common law couple that is splitting up should have to divide property like a married couple: Has a child together?

var.name: vd5_3
var.labl: When do you think a common law couple that is splitting up should have to divide property like a married couple: Has a written agreement to divide property according to the riles?

var.name: vd5_4
var.labl: When do you think a common law couple that is splitting up should have to divide property like a married couple: Other specified?

var.name: vd5_5
var.labl: When do you think a common law couple that is splitting up should have to divide property like a married couple: Don't know (volunteered)?

var.name: vd5_6
var.labl: When do you think a common law couple that is splitting up should have to divide property like a married couple: No response (volunteered)?

var.name: vd6
var.labl: Which of the following values is MOST important in any new law about dividing property between common law couples when they split up?

catgry.labl: Individuals should not have to divide property unless agree to do so
All couples should be treated the same, whether they are married or not
The law should recognize that marriage is special
The law should help the spouse/partner who has the least money
